nodes.bodyText: correlation(c1, c2)?
Is the fact that there are two nested aggregations relevant? Or is that just for illustration?
It is just an illustration to show how a grouped aggregation and a global aggregation are rewritten.

I think this is too constraining. We should be able to decorrelate any query that produces a scalar value, such as:
SELECT (
    SELECT k 
    FROM UNNEST(a) AS u(k) 
    LIMIT 1
)
FROM (VALUES
    ARRAY[1,2,3],
    ARRAY[4,5,6],
    ARRAY[]) t(a)

or even, simply:
SELECT (
    SELECT k 
    FROM UNNEST(a) AS u(k) 
)
FROM ...

which should fail if the nested subquery produces more than one row for each outer row.
The rewrite would likely have to involve some window function and a check to make sure that the count of rows with the same uniqueid is <= 1 (or else fail).
I would call this isSupportedUnnest and add short commment what does it mean (even if it would add duplication agains class-level javadoc)
nit: extract (AggregationNode) node as a variable (I know it will make method a bit longer.
Is it the same as hasNonEmptyGroupingSet()?
nit: optionalUnnestNode
to input rows
can we do that unconditionally and assume the unnecessary projection would be prunned afterwards?

Not quite. It is supposed to copy a projection that provides input for UnnestNode. So we cannot do it unconditionally, but need to check if there is a  projection below UnnestNode or not.
However, the condition can be simplified to checking if there is a projection (currently it checks if the projection is necessary for the UnnestNode). It will make the code clearer, and if we plan an unnecessary projection, it should be pruned afterwards.
There are no guarantees about the order of nodes returned by PlanNodeSearcher
The order is deterministic. PlanNodeSearcher is not documented, but it seems an intuitive expectation to me that findAll() should return nodes in order.

@kasiafi I am fine with assuming ordering, but can you please add a comment (and preferably test) for PlanNodeSearcher.searchFrom to document semantics.
Can be (or even preferably) in another PR.
@losipiuk I added a comment + test in #7024
What if there are multiple UNNESTs?

The search condition is written such that a single UNNEST is supported. Probably it could be extended to support multi-level (nested) unnesting. That could be a follow-up if we find we really need it.
I haven't thought about it in depth, but it seems that we'd have to capture ordinality symbol from the outermost (last) UNNEST and use it analogically to how ordinality of the only UNNEST is used in this rule.
Add tests with multiple unnest (e.g., FROM UNNEST(a), UNNEST(b), and tests with correlations at multiple levels (i.e., two or more levels of nesting)

FROM UNNEST(a), UNNEST(b)

In the subquery? No, that's not supported. This rule supports single correlated UNNEST. The mechanism of this rule is that it identifies a correlated subquery based on UNNEST, and "plants" the subquery (with all necessary modifications) on top of CorrelatedJoin's input. If we tried it with two UNNESTs, we'd have to duplicate the CorrelatedJoin's input plan, decorrelate UNNESTs and join.

tests with correlations at multiple levels (i.e., two or more levels of nesting)

There are tests like
"SELECT (SELECT max(count) FROM (SELECT count(v) AS count FROM UNNEST(id, val) u(i, v) GROUP BY i)) "
where correlation comes from a further outer scope.
I'll try to add some example where the innermost subquery is resolved and it enables decorrelation on another level.
I added a test with two levels of decorrelation.

If we have unique assigned for a, c1, c2 we do not have to put those in set of grouping columns. Just unique would be enough. Right?
Not sure if this is any harm though?
Do you know if for execution-wise one is better than the other?
Oh - never mind. This comment does not make sense. If they were not part of grouping set we would have to wrap them into arbitrary aggregation. Keep it.
